Stay strong! Stay healthy!

Sincerely,

Martin D. Cox, Ed.D.

Laurel Plains Student Madison Maione Receives Award of Merit
Congratulations to Madison Maione, a student at Laurel Plains Elementary, for being chosen as a National Reflections winner. She received an Award of Merit in Visual Arts for her piece "Eye, Myself," an incredible accomplishment!

"My drawing explores what makes me-me. I hope to inspire others to look within themselves like I did. I drew my passions, interests and desires and hope others will look within themselves and remember what theirs are too so they never give up on their dreams." - Madison Maione

Each year, over 300,000 students in Pre-K through Grade 12 create original works of art in response to a student-selected theme. The theme for the 2020-21 program was "I matter because..." Over 400 entries were receive from NYS and nearly 1000 entries from across the country moved on to the National Level.

Additional information can be found on the PTA Council's Website - https://ptacouncilccsd.weebly.com/reflections--scholarship-winners.html

Dear Clarkstown School Community:

We hope this communication finds you and your family members healthy and in good spirits.

The purpose of this letter is to provide clarity and accuracy as it pertains to matters involving the 2020-21 Clarkstown Central School District Budget. Specifically, it has come to our attention that inaccurate information has been shared by some in our community via a robocall communication, stating that CCSD School taxes have increased by 30% over the last 6 years.

This information shared in the robocall communication is inaccurate.

Instead, the correct average annual Tax Levy Increase has been 1.6% over the past 6 years:

2020-21 - 1.40% proposed
2019-20 - 2.27%
2018-19 - 2.08%
2017-18 - 1.91%
2016-17 - 0.12%
2015-16 - 1.84%

Please visit our website (www.ccsd.edu/budget) for additional information regarding the 2020-21 budget along with past budget information

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Tamara Bierker
Board of Education President

Martin D. Cox, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

post_text: “Bem-vindo à floresta tropical!” Third graders from Lakewood Elementary were immersed in a study of Brazil as “tour guides” took their classes on a virtual field trip through the Amazon Rainforest. Special area teachers and teaching assistants collaborated as chaperones to bring students together to share in this unique experience. Together they encountered poisonous dart frogs, colorful birds, screeching howler monkeys and even tarantulas! Full of wonder and awe, the children left with a natural urge to investigate well beyond this adventure. #ClarkstownCSD #CCSDAtHome

Another accolade for Clarkstown North and Clarkstown South! Both high schools have been recognized by the New York State Education Department for academic success and student outcomes.

In an announcement on April 23, NYSED identified CHSN and CHSS as “Recognition Schools.” Under the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) plan, Recognition Schools are those with high academic achievement and strong progress, that also perform acceptably for all subgroups for which they are accountable. This year’s designees represent 13 percent of New York State public schools.

Read more about this designation on the NYSED Website. #ClarkstownCSD #CCSDSchools

Dear Clarkstown Community and Staff:

Please be advised that we learned yesterday that a parent of a student from New City Elementary School in the Clarkstown School District tested positive for COVID-19 virus. Due to confidentiality considerations, we will not provide any further identifying information.

I am asking that we keep in our thoughts and prayers individuals who have been tested positive with the virus along with their family members.

For all in our community, if you experience any symptoms, including dry cough, fever or shortness of breath, please contact your physician or other health provider immediately for guidance. We recommend that everyone continue to follow the CDC's recommendation of hand washing, social distancing, covering the mouth, coughing and sneezing into a tissue, etc.

Sincerely,
Sue Sherlock
Health Services Coordinator

Martin Cox, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

Faculty and staff from both Clarkstown North and South high schools gathered today to hone best-practices in social-emotional learning. The joint professional development represents a midpoint check-in during Phase One of integrating the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence program. Peer-led breakout sessions focused on classroom strategies piloted by teachers who utilize the Yale “RULER” approach–recognizing, understanding, labeling, expressing and regulating strategies. These tools, including mood meters, meta moments, classroom charters and blueprints, allow teens to be more self-aware, resulting in improved student engagement and academic achievement and stronger student-teacher communication.

Beginning in September, all schools district-wide will be integrating social-emotional learning into their curricula. #ClarkstownCSD

Festa Winter Concert Season Begins
Posted by Superintendent Cox

The first of four Winter Concerts was held last night at Felix Festa Middle School.

Parents, students, and community members packed the school's auditorium to watch the 6th Grade Chorus and 7th Grade Chorus perform separately while combining for a total of 10 musical selections.

The 6th Grade Chorus students opened their concert under the direction of Music Teacher Matt Royal, who led students to selections including Boatmen Stomp, Once Upon A December, Rise Up, and An African Wish.

Music Teacher Niamh McCabe then led the 7th Grade Chorus to the following selections: Wayfaring Stranger, Stand by Me, Shine on Me, Blackbird, and I Want It That Way. Music Teacher DeWilton Lattimer was the pianist for both concerts.

Congratulations to the students and their teachers for their outstanding work while sharing the gift of music with the Festa school community!

The Concert Season continues tonight at 6:30 p.m., and again on January 21 and 22, also with start times at 6:30 p.m.

North Boys Cross Country Runners Finish First, Second to Win Dual Meet
Posted by Superintendent Cox

Alex Chamak and Michael Nunes set the pace from start to finish while leading North High School to a 24-33 Cross Country Dual Meet win against North Rockland on Tuesday.

Alex Chamak led all runners with a time of 16:45 and Michael Nunes crossed the line in second place at 17:10. North's Liam Rigney (6th - 17:34), Antony Parambi (7th - 19:09) and Preston Lee (8th - 18:11) all finished among the top 10 runners in the race that was held at Kennedy Park in New City.

Maya Ascher was North's top runner in the girls race with an 8th place finish and a time of 20:15. North's Grace Keywork was 11th (22:42), Jenna Schulze was 12th (22:56), Kyra Goyal (23:54) was 15th and Amy Schofield (25:17) was 17th.

North Rockland, a nationally ranked team, took the top seven spots and won the girls race 15-63. Two-time defending individual national champion Katelyn Tuohy, a Gatorade National Female Athlete of the Year Award Winner, won the girls race in a time of 17:59.
